title: Oscars: Best Picture — PGA Voting Closes. Which Film Benefits From the Preferential Ballot?
description: Variety Awards Circuit section is the home for all awards news and related content throughout the year, featuring the following: the official predictions for the upcoming Oscars, Emmys, Grammys and Tony Awards ceremonies, curated by Variety senior awards editor Clayton Davis. The prediction pages reflect the current standings in the race and do not reflect personal preferences for any individual […]
author: Clayton Davis
excerpt: 2025 Oscar best picture predictions include "Anora," "Conclave," “Emilia Pérez,” "Gladiator 2," "Dune 2," "Wicked," "Blitz," "Challengers" and "Maria"
text: Oscars: Best Picture — PGA Voting Closes. Which Film Benefits From the Preferential Ballot? Searchlight Pictures Variety Awards Circuit section is the home for all awards news and related content throughout the year, featuring the following: the official predictions for the upcoming Oscars, Emmys, Grammys and Tony Awards ceremonies, curated by Variety senior awards editor Clayton Davis. The prediction pages reflect the current standings in the race and do not reflect personal preferences for any individual contender. As other formal (and informal) polls suggest, competitions are fluid and subject to change based on buzz and events. Predictions are updated every Thursday. Explore Awards Circuit Predictions PagesOscars  |  Emmys  |  Grammys  |  Tonys Emilia Pérez. (Featured L-R) Zoe Saldaña as Rita Moro Castro and Karla Sofía Gascón as Emilia Pérez in Emilia Pérez. Cr. Netflix © 2024. Best Picture commentary (Updated Jan. 31, 2025): With 13 nominations, “Emilia Pérez” seems to have the logical edge (although recent controversies could derail that assertion). It has key guild nods and below-the-line Oscar mentions. But in this unpredictable year, historical trends are no guarantee. Major upcoming ceremonies like DGA, PGA and SAG may clarify the race — or make it even messier. The PGA will be crucial, as they use the same preferential ballot system as the Oscars. The PGA has often predicted best picture winners, showing that divisive films about a woman falling in love with a fish (“The Shape of Water”) or featuring butt plugs and hot dog fingers (“Everything Everywhere All at Once”) can win. If the more divisive “Emilia” or “Brutalist” wins PGA, it will solidify their frontrunner status. If not, the Oscars could mirror the chaotic splits of 2015, when “The Big Short,” “The Revenant,” and “Spotlight” each won major guild awards, with Oscar ultimately aligning with SAG. This year, the SAG Awards occur after final Oscar voting closes, meaning they won’t directly influence the Academy’s decision. With no clear frontrunner, this year’s race is as unpredictable as ever. And isn’t that what makes for an exciting Oscars ceremony? The 97th Oscars will be held on Sunday, March 2. All movie listings, titles, distributors, and credited artisans are not final and are subject to change. Since 1927, nominees and winners have been selected by members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS). Nineteen branches are represented within the nearly 11,000-person membership. The branches are actors, animators, associates, casting directors, cinematographers, costume designers, directors, documentary, executives, film editors, makeup and hairstylists, marketing and public relations, members-at-large, members-at-large (artists’ representatives), music, producers, production design, short films, sound, visual effects and writers.
html:
Oscars: Best Picture — PGA Voting Closes. Which Film Benefits From the Preferential Ballot?

Variety Awards Circuit section is the home for all awards news and related content throughout the year, featuring the following: the official predictions for the upcoming Oscars, Emmys, Grammys and Tony Awards ceremonies, curated by Variety senior awards editor Clayton Davis. The prediction pages reflect the current standings in the race and do not reflect personal preferences for any individual contender. As other formal (and informal) polls suggest, competitions are fluid and subject to change based on buzz and events. Predictions are updated every Thursday.

Explore Awards Circuit Predictions Pages
Oscars  |  Emmys  |  Grammys  |  Tonys

Best Picture commentary (Updated Jan. 31, 2025): With 13 nominations, “Emilia Pérez” seems to have the logical edge (although recent controversies could derail that assertion). It has key guild nods and below-the-line Oscar mentions. But in this unpredictable year, historical trends are no guarantee. Major upcoming ceremonies like DGA, PGA and SAG may clarify the race — or make it even messier.

The PGA will be crucial, as they use the same preferential ballot system as the Oscars. The PGA has often predicted best picture winners, showing that divisive films about a woman falling in love with a fish (“The Shape of Water”) or featuring butt plugs and hot dog fingers (“Everything Everywhere All at Once”) can win.

If the more divisive “Emilia” or “Brutalist” wins PGA, it will solidify their frontrunner status. If not, the Oscars could mirror the chaotic splits of 2015, when “The Big Short,” “The Revenant,” and “Spotlight” each won major guild awards, with Oscar ultimately aligning with SAG. This year, the SAG Awards occur after final Oscar voting closes, meaning they won’t directly influence the Academy’s decision.

With no clear frontrunner, this year’s race is as unpredictable as ever. And isn’t that what makes for an exciting Oscars ceremony?

The 97th Oscars will be held on Sunday, March 2. All movie listings, titles, distributors, and credited artisans are not final and are subject to change.

  • Eligible Titles (Best Picture)

  • More Information (Oscars: Best Picture)

    About the Academy Awards

    The Academy Awards, better known as the Oscars, is Hollywood’s most prestigious artistic award in the film industry. Since 1927, nominees and winners have been selected by members of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences (AMPAS). Nineteen branches are represented within the nearly 11,000-person membership. The branches are actors, animators, associates, casting directors, cinematographers, costume designers, directors, documentary, executives, film editors, makeup and hairstylists, marketing and public relations, members-at-large, members-at-large (artists’ representatives), music, producers, production design, short films, sound, visual effects and writers.
